park.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.

images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

eatery.description: With respect to the Tadich Grill in SF and Musso & Frank's in Hollywood, our choice is this legendary spot in Bayview. Anyone who has spent time playing soccer on Silver Ave or driving down Bayshore Blvd or just living around SF knows the Old Clam House's iconic sign and that giant clam sitting on the side of the roof and the fact that it's the oldest restaurant in the same location in SF (again, apologies to Tadich). But more people should know about the incredible clam bake cioppino and the amazing kettle bread that's brought out with hot clam juice and the restaurant's own 'Milwaukee steam beer,' which our SF-based editor swears by.

attraction.name: Giant L.L. Bean Boot
attraction.description: If this isn’t the most Instagrammed spot in Maine, it should be. The L.L. Bean flagship store has a 16-foot-tall rubber boot in front of it, perfect for posing with however you choose.

park.description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

images.title: Starviewing
images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

eatery.description: When in Iowa, do as the Greeks do. About two hours north of Des Moines lies a steakhouse that's been around in one form or another since the '20s, and the steaks are all prepared one way: Greek-style. This means they're broiled in olive oil and doused with a special blend of Greek seasoning and secret ingredients, and the result is that you can cut your steak with a fork. The walls are plastered with old-timey movie posters featuring Chaplin and John Wayne in a cozy 50-seat space.

attraction.name: Ghostbusters Headquarters
attraction.description: The Tribeca firehouse Hook and Ladder Company 8 was used as the Ghostbusters headquarters in the film Ghostbusters and it’s still around and super easy to get to. This New York City attraction is right off of a subway line and full of nods to its film history. According to Roadside America, when actor Harold Ramis died in 2014, fans set up a memorial on the sidewalk outside of the fire house.

park.description: The Gateway Arch reflects St. Louis' role in the Westward Expansion of the United States during the nineteenth century. The park is a memorial to Thomas Jefferson's role in opening the West, to the pioneers who helped shape its history, and to Dred Scott who sued for his freedom in the Old Courthouse.

images.title: West Entrance to the Gateway Arch Visitor Center
images.altText: West Entrance to the Gateway Arch Visitor Center
images.caption: Welcome to the Gateway Arch

images.title: Gateway Arch
images.altText: Gateway Arch
images.caption: Over a million people visit the Gateway Arch each year.

images.title: The Gateway Arch reflected
images.altText: The Gateway Arch reflected in the waters of of the north pond
images.caption: A walk around the Gateway Arch grounds provide many chances to view the Arch from many different angles.

images.title: Gateway Arch at Sunrise
images.altText: Gateway Arch at Sunrise
images.caption: The sunrise coming up behind the Gateway Arch.

images.title: Reaching for the Clouds
images.altText: Arch and clouds
images.caption: Arch reaching toward the clouds.

images.title: Old Courthouse
images.altText: Dred and Harriet Scott statue in front of the columns of the Old Courthouse in the morning light
images.caption: The Old Courthouse

images.title: The Old Courthouse
images.altText: looking across the green lawn in Smith Square to the Old Courthouse
images.caption: The Old Courthouse

images.title: Cherry trees in bloom
images.altText: The Gateway Arch and Old Courthouse with a row of pink blooming cherry trees in front
images.caption: The blooming cherry trees in Kiener Plaza provide a wonderful foreground for the Gateway Arch and Old Courthouse in spring.

eatery.description: Located just east of Great Falls -- with its highfalutin waterfalls and Tiki mermaids -- the small town of Fort Benton itself is so old and iconic that a good portion of the town is a historic district thanks to its rich history of steamboats. The Grand Union Hotel is also on the National Registry of Historic Places, having established itself seven years before Montana even became a state, long before the city fell on hard times thanks to the railroad. Now restored to its original glory, the old hotel offers up a high-end, seasonally based menu in the Union Grille, which specializes in European and Indian twists on Montana classics, and where for 11 months a year (January's a no-no) you can gorge yourself before sleeping it off in one of the hotel's posh rooms.

attraction.name: Giant Abraham Lincoln
attraction.description: You can take a funny picture with an absolutely enormous Abraham Lincoln in Boise, Idaho. People have enjoyed posing with this comically large statute since its unveiling in 2010.

park.fullName: New River Gorge National Park and Preserve.
park.description: A rugged, whitewater river flowing northward through deep canyons, the New River is among the oldest rivers on the continent. The park encompasses over 70,000 acres of land along the New River, is rich in cultural and natural history, and offers an abundance of scenic and recreational opportunities.

images.title: Sunrise at Diamond Point
images.altText: sun rising over the New River Gorge
images.caption: Sun rising over the New River Gorge from Diamond Point on the Endless Wall Trail.

images.title: New River Gorge Bridge
images.altText: bridge spanning the river
images.caption: The New River Gorge Bridge spans across the New River.

images.title: Horseshoe Bend from Grandview
images.altText: bend in the river
images.caption: The Horseshoe Bend in the New River from Grandview

images.title: Thurmond Depot
images.altText: railroad tracks and depot
images.caption: Thurmond Depot

images.title: Sandstone Falls
images.altText: waterfall spanning the river
images.caption: Sandstone Falls spans the New River

images.title: Foggy morning
images.altText: fog and mountains
images.caption: Fog settles in the gorge

images.title: Rhododendron at Turkey Spur
images.altText: pink rhododendron and view of the gorge and river
images.caption: View from Turkey Spur at Grandview

images.title: Waterfall on Dowdy Creek
images.altText: waterfall and stream
images.caption: Waterfall on Dowdy Creek

eatery.description: While that one scene in Wayne's World helped define Delaware for an entire generation, every generation of Delawareans knows Deer Park as a historic spot where Edgar Allan Poe once hung out in the 1800s, right before he founded the Baltimore Ravens football team. It continues to operate as a Newark staple -- a place where townies and college students alike enjoy burgers, nachos, and a pint of local-ish Dogfish Head.

attraction.name: Spinning Yellow Giant
attraction.description: Only in Omaha can you see a 20-foot-tall man wearing a yellow rain coat, rotating in front of a car wash (and in multiple locations). These car washes are also staffed by much smaller animatronic mannequins, all wearing similar yellow raincoats, to delight and terrify you throughout your car wash experience.

park.fullName: New River Gorge National Park and Preserve.
park.description: A rugged, whitewater river flowing northward through deep canyons, the New River is among the oldest rivers on the continent. The park encompasses over 70,000 acres of land along the New River, is rich in cultural and natural history, and offers an abundance of scenic and recreational opportunities.

images.title: Sunrise at Diamond Point
images.altText: sun rising over the New River Gorge
images.caption: Sun rising over the New River Gorge from Diamond Point on the Endless Wall Trail.

images.altText: bridge spanning the river
images.caption: The New River Gorge Bridge spans across the New River.

images.altText: bend in the river

images.title: Waterfall on Dowdy Creek
images.altText: waterfall and stream
images.caption: Waterfall on Dowdy Creek

eatery.description: New York is the entry point for many immigrants as they make their way into the US, and back before the Lower East Side had a Whole Foods, it was home to many of those same immigrants and their families. Katz's has been a linchpin of the neighborhood for over 100 years. It's a place where tourists and locals unite over one thing: the consumption of outrageously large meat sandwiches. If there's anything more American than a panoply of cultures, ages, and social classes coming together over food, I don't know what it is.

attraction.name: Elvis Memorial Chapel
attraction.description: You wouldn’t ever think Elvis Presley would have a place in Arizona, but “the King” lives on in Apache Junction. The Elvis Memorial Chapel survived the devastating fires at the former Apacheland Movie Ranch and has since been reconstructed at the Superstition Mountain Museum.

attraction.name: Town Named Hot Coffee
attraction.description: There is a town named Hot Coffee in Mississippi, but if you blink you might miss it. The teeny tiny town is now just a green highway sign and an abandoned grocery store. People often stop to take photos that reaffirm their love of java.

park.description: Visit Arches to discover a landscape of contrasting colors, land forms, and textures unlike any other in the world. The park has over 2,000 natural stone arches and hundreds of soaring pinnacles, massive rock fins, and giant balanced rocks. This red-rock wonderland will amaze you with its formations, refresh you with its trails, and inspire you with its sunsets.

images.title: The Organ with Potholes
images.altText: a stone monolith reflected in standing water
images.caption: The Organ rock formation is reflected in one of many natural potholes.

images.title: Double O Arch
images.altText: a broad, red arch with rock pinnacles in the background
images.caption: Double O Arch is one of many large arches in the Devils Garden area

images.title: Delicate Arch
images.altText: a stone arch
images.caption: Delicate Arch is perhaps the most famous natural arch in the world.

images.title: Milky Way over the Garden of Eden
images.altText: the Milky Way arcs above silhouetted stone pinnacles
images.caption: Arches offers some excellent night sky viewing.

images.title: Park Avenue Trail
images.altText: two hikers descend a broad wash with tall rock walls on either side.
images.caption: The Park Avenue trail is one of many hiking trails at Arches, ranging from easy to strenuous.

eatery.description: Five generations of the McClard family have been working the smoker since they opened their spot in the '20s, which is a type of nepotism no one who's ever eaten their ribs or chicken is complaining about. One of the most popular dishes is the tamale spread, a vast pile of food that includes tamales covered in Fritos, beans, chopped meat, onions, and cheese -- it was initially thrown together in the early '70s to help one of the dishwashers sober up, but eventually caught on with the customers. It's uniquely McClard's and uniquely Arkansas.

Alabama's place in the great lexicon of barbecue rests squarely on the shoulders of one man: Big Bob Gibson. While other BBQ regions were dancing with brisket and ribs and pork, in 1925, Gibson started smoking chicken in a hand-dug pit in his backyard and serving folks on a picnic table. (He also served pork, but that's such a side note to the chicken here.) In addition to making chicken the star -- rather than the weird, dry BBQ’d poultry coated in a congealed sauce that's served at every company picnic ever -- Gibson rolled out his now-famous, peppery mayo-cider vinegar-lemon white sauce that’s synonymous with Alabama barbecue.

attraction.name: Elvis Memorial Chapel
attraction.description: You wouldn’t ever think Elvis Presley would have a place in Arizona, but “the King” lives on in Apache Junction. The Elvis Memorial Chapel survived the devastating fires at the former Apacheland Movie Ranch and has since been reconstructed at the Superstition Mountain Museum.

attraction.name: Snake World
attraction.description: The next time you’re in Arkansas, be sure to stop by Snake World! Owner Dale Ertel claims that the tourist attraction houses over 70 snakes, which is even more than the Little Rock Zoo. The reviews on Trip Advisor are all glowing, and warn visitors not to be dissuaded by Snake World’s sketchy exterior.
